Situation2: You notice a small, contained liquid spill in a walkway that needs to be O39eaned up immediately to prevent slips.
Story: I’m at the supermarket with my son, trying to get groceries before my shift at the construction site. He darts away from me, weaving between carts and displays, laughing as he goes. I know I should stop him, teach him that running indoors isn’t safe or respectful. That’s what a good parent does—sets boundaries, explains right from wrong, keeps their child and others safe. But just as I reach for his arm, my phone buzzes. It’s a message from my foreman: there’s a spill on the walkway at the site, and I’m the closest one. If it isn’t cleaned up right away, someone could get hurt. I can almost hear his voice in my head, reminding me that safety is everyone’s responsibility, that I need to set an example for the crew. My heart pounds as I look at my son, still running, and then at my phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. I know I can’t be in two places at once, but both expect me to act now.
